Comment: One of the most ancient of chess defenses, the Philidor is these days considered drawish. White typically achieves a spatial advantage while Black builds a hard shell around his King and plays to weather the storm. Of course, theory isn't always the same as practice; or, as they say in the NFL, "That's why they play the games."

It's tempting to say each side is playing "If you ignore me, I'll ignore you," but that's not what's happening at all. In fact, each player is carefully jockeying for the advantage in the center, and the tension is building.

!? -- I also considered 18. Ng4 Bg4  19.h3 with mere equality ...the text move, after all, exchanges Black's bad Knight for one of White's good ones. But I felt that playing the N to d5 actually gave me a lasting positional advantage: after an exchange there, both of White's Bishops are aimed right at Black's King, and a break at f4 would be easy to engineer, opening the diagonals. Plus, with my QB on c3 Black's hope of expanding on the Q-side is stymied. Not an easy position to win for White, for sure, but the chances to create and use pressure seem to be mine not Black's.
